author: Emma O'Brien
title: Euro Holds Drop as Greece Misses IMF Payment While Gold Advances
text:
The euro held declines after the International Monetary Fund confirmed Greece failed to make its debt payment, adding that it will consider a request from the beleaguered nation for an extension on the obligation. New Zealand stocks rose a second day and gold climbed.
The euro was little changed at $1.1138 by 7:45 a.m. in Tokyo, after slipping 0.8 percent Tuesday. The NZX 50 Index added 0.2 percent in Wellington, while index futures from Japan to Australia were mixed in most recent trade. Chicago futures trading is delayed until 8:45 p.m. New York time to account for the leap second . Gold gained 0.2 percent to $1,175.05 an ounce in the spot market. The Standard & Poor’s 500 Index rose 0.3 percent, paring its first three-month drop in 10 quarters.
Greece missed a deadline for repaying $1.7 billion, joining countries from Cuba to Zimbabwe in failing to pay back the IMF after bailout talks with its creditors imploded. The IMF board has been informed that Greece is in arrears, spokesman Gerry Rice said by e-mail. Global equities fell for the first time in three quarters in the three months to June 30 as the Greek crisis ramped up and traders boosted bets the Federal Reserve will start raising interest rates this year.
Greece’s failure to make the payment “is not really the issue now, the bigger question is what response the ECB takes to the missed payment with respect to the provision of Emergency Liquidity Assistance,” Philip Borkin, a senior economist in Auckland at ANZ Bank New Zealand Ltd., wrote in a client note Wednesday. “Even following this Sunday’s referendum, there may still be more questions than answers, and so this heightened level of of uncertainty could be part of the market backdrop for a while yet.”
Tankan, PMIs Japan’s quarterly Tankan indexes are due Wednesday, along with South Korean inflation data and manufacturing and services purchasing managers’ readings from China. The final June reading on the HSBC Holdings Plc/ Markit Economics China factory PMI is also due. Markets in Hong Kong and Thailand are closed for holidays.
An 11th hour proposal from the Greek government was shut down by Angela Merkel Tuesday, with the German chancellor rejecting talks before the July 5 referendum. Capital controls are starting to be felt in the indebted nation, where bank machine withdrawals have been limited and the stock exchange shuttered. The euro-area’s bailout package to Greece also expired June 30.
U.S. Moves European Central Bank policy makers would have to consider the effect of any missed payment on the solvency of Greek banks when they discuss the level of liquidity assistance on Wednesday, with the outcome having potential implications for Greece’s membership in the euro. Klaus Regling, the head of the main euro-area bailout fund, has said it has the option of demanding accelerated debt payments from Greece if it doesn’t pay the IMF.
The S&P 500 rallied Tuesday following its steepest one-day slump since April 2014. The gauge slid 0.2 percent in the quarter, extending its worst start to a year since 2010. The S&P 500 is up 0.2 percent in 2015, after three years of double-digit gains in the period, on prospects the economy is strong enough to withstand higher rates this year.
The Stoxx Europe 600 Index sank 1.3 percent Tuesday to cap a 4 percent slide in the three-month period.
